O R I G I N A L  A R T I C L E
Bifactor model of effortful control and impulsivity and their 
prospective prediction of ego resiliency
Frances L. Wang1
  |  Nancy Eisenberg2  |  Tracy L. Spinrad3
1Department of Psychiatry, University of 
Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA
2Department of Psychology, Arizona State 
University, Tempe, Arizona
3T. Denny Sanford School of Social and 
Family Dynamics, Arizona State University, 
Tempe, Arizona
Correspondence
Frances L. Wang, Department of Psychiatry, 
University of Pittsburgh, 3811 O’Hara 
Street, Pittsburgh, PA 15213.
Email: wangfl@upmc.edu
Funding information
National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and 
Alcoholism, Grant/Award Number: F31 
AA023128 and T32/AA007453; National 
Institute of Mental Health, Grant/Award 
Number: R01 MH60838
Abstract
Objective: Children’s effortful control and impulsivity are important predictors of 
the personality trait, ego resiliency (i.e., resiliency). Most researchers have not con-
sidered the fact that effortful control and impulsivity share substantial conceptual 
and empirical overlap, yet they also have been shown to be distinct. We tested a bi-
factor model of effortful control and impulsivity to characterize their shared and 
unique variance, the prospective prediction of resiliency by the factors of the bifactor 
model, and moderation by sex and age.
Method: In a longitudinal study of children (N = 214; 76.5% non‐Hispanic 
Caucasian, 12.2% Hispanic, 11.3% other race/ethnicity), parent‐ and teacher‐reported 
effortful control and impulsivity, as well as behavioral measures of effortful control, 
were assessed on two occasions (T1: 4.5–8 years; T2: 6–10 years). Parent‐reported 
resiliency was used as a covariate (T1) and the outcome (T3: 8–12 years).
Results: The bifactor model yielded a common effortful inhibitory control factor, 
pure attentional control factor, and pure impulsivity factor. Pure impulsivity and pure 
attentional control positively predicted resiliency, but only for girls. Effortful inhibi-
tory control did not uniquely predict resiliency.
Conclusion: Disentangling the shared and unique aspects of effortful control and 
impulsivity could clarify the roles they play in important outcomes, such as 
resiliency.
K E Y W O R D S
bifactor model, effortful control, ego resiliency, impulsivity, sex differences
920  |     
WANG et al.
1.1  |  Temperamental predictors of resiliency
Investigators have conceptualized personality traits, such as 
resiliency, as having roots in temperament (Rothbart, Ahadi, 
& Evans, 2000). Temperament has been defined as, “consti-
tutionally‐based individual differences in reactivity and regu-
lation” (Rothbart & Bates, 2006, p. 100). Effortful control is 
the regulatory component of temperament, which is defined 
as “the efficiency of executive attention‐including the abil-
ity to inhibit a dominant response and/or to activate a sub-
dominant response, to plan, and to detect errors” (Rothbart & 
Bates, 2006, p. 129). Although impulsivity is a widely used 
term that has been assigned a variety of different meanings 
(see Whiteside & Lynam, 2001 for a more comprehensive 
review), we define impulsivity as a reactive component of 
temperament describing one’s speed of response initiation 
and level of surgent approach behavior (Rothbart & Bates, 
2006). Individuals with high levels of impulsivity may ap-
proach rewards and pursue desires in an unthinking manner, 
whereas individuals with very low levels of impulsivity tend 
to be inhibited, withdrawn, and rigid. Although impulsivity 
and effortful control both involve control (or lack thereof), 
impulsivity is considered a more involuntary and automatic 
form of control, whereas effortful control is considered more 
flexible and voluntary (Eisenberg et al., 2004; Nigg, 2017). 
Researchers also believe, and have evidence suggesting, that 
the overt expression of impulsive tendencies can be modu-
lated or changed, at least to some degree, by effortful control 
(Eisenberg et al., 2004).
Impulsivity and effortful control have been shown to be 
important predictors of resiliency. Researchers have shown 
that children with greater effortful control are viewed by 
adults as higher in resiliency (Cumberland‐Li, Eisenberg, & 
Reiser, 2004; Eisenberg, Spinrad, & Morris, 2002; Eisenberg 
et al., 2004). Children high in effortful control are skilled at 
regulating negative emotions when faced with aversive ex-
periences, which potentially allows them to adapt and re-
bound more quickly. The relation between impulsivity and 
resiliency tends to be more complex. For example, findings 
of one study demonstrated that children (4–8 years old) with 
low levels of impulsivity had the lowest levels of resiliency, 
whereas children with average and high levels of resiliency 
were relatively higher in resiliency (but similar in resiliency 
to one another; i.e., a quadratic effect; Eisenberg et al., 2002). 
These findings suggest that low impulsivity undermines re-
siliency, possibly because children low in impulsivity react 
rigidly to novel stressors and lack the spontaneity to adapt 
to changes. Eisenberg et al. (2003) also found that higher 
levels of ego control, which is conceptually similar to low 
impulsivity, was associated with poorer resiliency. However, 
this finding only became apparent after controlling for ef-
fortful control. Prior to controlling for effortful control, the 
association in the latter study had been reversed, suggesting 
that ego control more purely reflected the intended construct 
only after partialling out the confounding effect of effortful 
control. Indeed, high ego control likely reflects high effortful 
control to a certain extent because these constructs may be 
difficult for adult observers to distinguish. It also has been 
suggested that once one controls for low levels of effortful 
control that might be evidenced in impulsivity, what is left in 
the impulsivity construct is spontaneity and flexibility unre-
lated to lack of self‐regulation (e.g., Eisenberg et al., 2004). 
In sum, children with lower levels of impulsivity might dis-
play lower levels of resiliency (linear or quadratic), and this 
relation might become more evident after controlling for ef-
fortful control. This body of research suggests that, in addi-
tion to teaching children self‐regulatory skills more broadly, 
resiliency will be strengthened when children are taught to 
regulate impulsive behavior resulting from a lack of foresight 
(high impulsivity) as well as to regulate rigidity and inflexi-
bility (low impulsivity).
It is important to note that we view effortful control, im-
pulsivity, and resiliency as constructs that are correlated, 
but still distinct. Although resiliency has been shown to be 
predicted by effortful control and impulsivity, this trait is 
expected to be predicted by other factors as well, including 
other temperamental traits, learning, and the nature of con-
textual stressors (Eisenberg et al., 2004). In addition, resil-
iency specifically measures how well an individual adapts to 
stressful circumstances, whereas effortful control and impul-
sivity do not.
1.2  |  Overlap between effortful control and 
impulsivity
The present study examined the roles of childhood tem-
peramental effortful control and impulsivity in predicting 
resiliency in late childhood/early adolescence. However, un-
derstanding these relations requires consideration of the fact 
that effortful control and impulsivity show substantial con-
ceptual and statistical overlap. Researchers have found that 
effortful control and impulsivity are negatively correlated 
(e.g., sometimes as high as r = −0.75; Eisenberg et al., 2013; 
Wang, Chassin, Eisenberg, & Spinrad, 2015). This inverse 
correlation seems most likely due to effortful control involv-
ing high levels of behavioral inhibitory control (the ability 
to effortfully inhibit behavior) whereas impulsivity suggests 
low inhibition of behavior. Despite this high degree of over-
lap, researchers also found robust evidence for their distinc-
tiveness (Eisenberg et al., 2013; Nigg, 2017; Wang et al., 
2015). Using multiple behavioral and questionnaire measures 
of effortful control and impulsivity, Eisenberg et al. (2013) 
found that these two constructs loaded on different latent fac-
tors at three time points in early childhood. Effortful control 
and impulsivity are distinct, but correlated, constructs (see 
also Wang et al., 2015).

Most researchers have only tested one‐, two‐, or three‐
factor models of effortful control and impulsivity, with cor-
relations among factors to account for the shared variance. 
A critical oversight in the literature, including prior stud-
ies in this sample (i.e., Eisenberg et al., 2004), is that few 
researchers have modeled both the high degree of shared 
variance between these two traits, as well as what is distinct 
to each. This suggests that most existing models of effortful 
control and impulsivity do not adequately reflect the data 
and may miss important conclusions about children’s de-
velopment. By modeling the overlap and unique aspects of 
effortful control and impulsivity, it may be possible to fur-
ther clarify the role of self‐regulation in various aspects of 
developmental psychopathology, such as resiliency (Nigg, 
2017).
1.3  |  Utility of a bifactor model
The bifactor model can capture the overlap and unique as-
pects of a set of constructs. In this model, a “general” factor 
encompasses all of the factor indicators, and some number of 
“specific” factors encompass only a subset of the factor indi-
cators (Chen, West, & Sousa, 2006). In this study, we tested 
an a priori bifactor model of effortful control and impulsiv-
ity. This model consists of one “specific” or pure effortful 
control factor representing what is unique to effortful control, 
one “specific” or pure impulsivity factor representing what is 
unique to impulsivity, and one “general” factor representing 
the common variance in these constructs (hereafter referred 
to as the general control factor). Setting correlations among 
these factors to zero ensures that the factors represent unique 
variance after partialling out variance from the other factors.
Previous empirical findings support modeling the shared 
variance between temperament/personality traits using hi-
erarchical factor models, in which lower‐order factors are 
factor indicators of a higher‐order “general” factor. Indeed, 
several studies using child and adult samples and a variety 
of personality/temperament models (including the Big Five) 
demonstrated that a general personality/temperament factor 
accounted for the common variance among the lower‐order 
traits (Costa & McCrae, 1995; Rushton, Bons, & Hur, 2008). 
These studies support the notion that that there exists a com-
monality among traits lying on different dimensions that 
should be modeled. Note that a bifactor model is of more 
interest than a hierarchical model to represent the shared 
variance between effortful control and impulsivity. Unlike in 
hierarchical models, in bifactor models: (a) the magnitude of 
the associations among specific factors and each of its in-
dicators can be directly assessed; (b) it is easier to examine 
prediction by the specific factors over and above the general 
factor; and (c) it can be assessed whether hypothesized spe-
cific factors are independent of the general factor (Chen et 
al., 2006).
Although the conceptual meaning of the shared variance 
between effortful control and impulsivity is unclear, it is pos-
sible that it captures an aspect of self‐regulation—perhaps 
the ability to effortfully inhibit behavior (i.e., inhibitory con-
trol)—that adult observers are unable to disentangle when 
reporting on children’s effortful control versus impulsivity. 
For example, children low on impulsivity may be viewed as 
effortfully regulated (whether or not they are), as are children 
who effortfully inhibit their behavior when it is appropriate 
to do so. The “specific” effortful control and impulsivity 
factors might also be more meaningful and robust predic-
tors of resiliency because they represent purer measures of 
each construct. The results obtained using this particular 
method may differ in important ways from prior work in 
this and other samples that examined temperamental char-
acteristics separately (e.g., Eisenberg et al., 2002, 2003); if 
so, this would support the theoretic importance of modeling 
the shared and unique variance among temperamental char-
acteristics when predicting future outcomes. Thus, we tested 
this bifactor model and its prediction of resiliency to clarify 
the meaning of the shared variance between effortful control 
and impulsivity and shed new light on the roles of effortful 
control and impulsivity in prospectively predicting children’s 
resiliency. We modeled reporter bias in measures of effortful 
control, impulsivity, and resiliency, and used multiple modes 
of assessment, thus strengthening the interpretability of their 
associations.
1.4  |  Moderation by age and sex
It is important to understand whether the pure effortful con-
trol, pure impulsivity, and general factors predict resiliency 
differently for younger and older children or for girls and 
boys. Research shows that effortful control generally in-
creases as children get older (Kochanska, Murray, & Harlan, 
2000; Murphy, Eisenberg, Fabes, Shepard, & Guthrie, 1999). 
Because age‐related increases in effortful control might 
allow children to more effectively regulate impulsivity, pure 
impulsivity might be a less robust predictor of resiliency for 
older compared to younger children. Indeed, researchers sug-
gest that the effect of impulsivity on children’s externalizing 
problems, while controlling for effortful control, disappears 
at older ages (albeit still evident in zero‐order correlations; 
Eisenberg et al., 2004; Valiente et al., 2003).
Few researchers have tested whether the relation between 
effortful control and resiliency is moderated by age. Although 
effortful control has sometimes predicted low levels of in-
ternalizing and externalizing problems (outcomes related 
to resiliency) more strongly for younger (4 years old) than 
for older participants (5 and 6 years old; Dennis, Brotman, 
Huang, & Gouley, 2007), in other studies the strength of 
prediction by effortful control has not changed with age (in-
ternalizing and externalizing problems in 10–14 year olds;

WANG et al.
Valiente et al., 2006). It is possible that effortful control more 
strongly predicts outcomes in younger children, but it does 
not differentially predict outcomes by age starting in middle 
childhood. Nonetheless, none of these studies specifically ex-
amined resiliency as the outcome. It seemed possible that ef-
fortful control differentially predicts resiliency with age, but 
we were unsure about the exact nature of this pattern. Finally, 
few researchers have examined whether age moderates the 
relations among general temperamental or personality factors 
to variables such as ego resiliency. It is difficult to hypothe-
size whether the general control factor would be moderated 
by age (after the early years when effortful control is rapidly 
emerging) in predicting resiliency.
There are clear sex differences in effortful control and im-
pulsivity: girls tend to have higher effortful control and lower 
impulsivity than do boys (Else‐Quest, Hyde, Goldsmith, & 
Van Hulle, 2006). If these mean‐level differences also re-
flect differences in variability, effortful control and impul-
sivity might predict resiliency differently for boys and girls. 
Moreover, Chuang, Lamb, and Hwang (2006) found that boys 
had significantly higher resiliency than did girls during child-
hood, but they had lower resiliency than girls in adolescence. 
This pattern of mean differences might indicate distinct un-
derlying etiologies of resiliency for boys and girls, and thus, 
potentially different temperamental predictors. Although it 
seems quite possible that sex moderates the relation between 
temperament and resiliency, it is difficult to predict the exact 
nature of these interactions due to a lack of corresponding 
empirical literature on the topic.
1.5  |  The current study
The current study tested a bifactor model of effortful control 
and impulsivity in childhood. We hypothesized that such a 
model would fit the data well because research shows high 
correlations between these two temperamental traits (but has 
not explicitly modeled this shared variance), and that each of 
these temperamental traits is distinct (Eisenberg et al., 2013; 
Wang et al., 2015). Next, because prior studies of the same 
sample that used resiliency as an outcome did not capture 
the shared variance between effortful control and impulsiv-
ity (Eisenberg et al., 2002, 2003), we extended the literature 
by testing whether childhood pure effortful control, pure 
impulsivity, and general control factors predicted resiliency 
in late childhood/early adolescence, both with and without 
controlling for prior resiliency. This method allowed a test of 
whether these temperamental traits were related to resiliency 
over time, as well as whether these traits predicted resiliency 
above and beyond the stability of resiliency. We expected 
greater pure effortful control and pure impulsivity to predict 
greater resiliency. We were unsure if and how the general 
control factor would predict resiliency. Moderation of these 
paths by age and sex was tested. We tentatively hypothesized 
that pure impulsivity would more strongly predict resiliency 
for younger than for older children (Valiente et al., 2003). 
We did not form hypotheses about moderation by sex or 
whether general or effortful control factors would be moder-
ated by age.
2  | 
METHOD
2.1  |  Participants
Participants were recruited for a longitudinal study (Eisenberg 
et al., 2004) from local schools and using newspaper ads and 
flyers placed at after‐school programs and children’s stores. 
Prior to being chosen for participation, parents completed 
the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL; Achenbach, 1991a, 
1991b). All children with T scores of 60 or above on either 
internalizing or externalizing problems were chosen for 
participation (Achenbach, 1991a, 1991b). Children with T 
scores below 60 were also included in the larger study and 
matched as closely as possible on sex, parent education and 
occupation, age, and race. Thus, this longitudinal sample rep-
resented a wide range of scores on the CBCL. Specifically, 
55.1% of the children had a T ≥ 60 on externalizing problems 
and 53.7% had a T score ≥60 on internalizing (N = 214 at 
T1). At least partial data were available for 193 children at 
T2 and 185 at T3.
The current study used data from T1 (4.5–8 years old; 
M = 6.08, SD = 0.75), T2 (6–10 years old, M = 7.66, SD 
= 0.83), and T3 (8–12 years old, M = 9.74, SD = 0.93). 
Individuals who dropped out at both T2 and T3 assessments 
(n = 12) were compared against those who did not on demo-
graphic variables and measures that were available at T1. 
Participants who dropped out were more likely to be Native 
American, χ2(1) = 11.72, p < 0.001, and to have lower par-
ent‐reported T1 resiliency, t = −2.57, p = 0.01, and lower 
teacher‐reported attention focusing, t = −2.73, p = 0.01. See 
Table 1 for sample characteristics. Note that the racial/ethnic 
composition of the sample roughly approximates the ethnic 
composition of those residing in Arizona, the geographic 
region in which data were collected (U.S. Census Bureau, 
2000).
2.2  |  Procedures
At all three assessments, children and parents (typically 
mothers) participated in an experimental session at a univer-
sity laboratory and completed questionnaires at a university 
laboratory or at home. Questionnaires were sent home to 
the other parent (if available) and returned by mail. Parents 
were asked permission to send questionnaires to the child’s 
teacher. Some participants who moved continued to par-
ticipate by mail. Consent or assent (the latter for younger

2.3  |  Measures
2.3.1  |  Demographic variables
At T1, primary caregivers (henceforth referred to as parents; 
94.8% mothers and 5.2% fathers) reported on children’s sex, 
age, race/ethnicity, and their own education in years. The 
highest level of education obtained by mother or father was 
used as a covariate to index socioeconomic status (SES) be-
cause this variable might be the most stable and sensitive in-
dicator of SES risk for youths (Williams & Collins, 1995; see 
Table 1).
2.3.2  |  Children’s impulsivity
At both T1 and T2, parents and teachers reported (1 = ex-
tremely untrue; 7 = extremely true) on children’s impulsiv-
ity using the Child Behavior Questionnaire (CBQ; Rothbart, 
Ahadi, Hershey, & Fisher, 2001). Some items included, 
“Usually rushes into an activity without thinking about it” 
and “Sometimes interrupts others when they are speaking.” 
Separate parent‐ or teacher‐reported impulsivity composites 
were formed at both T1 and T2 by averaging items for impul-
sivity. Cronbach’s alpha for parent‐reported impulsivity was 
0.81 (T1) and 0.79 (T2) and for teacher‐reported impulsivity 
was 0.89 (T1) and 0.84 (T2).
2.3.3  |  Children’s effortful control
T1 and T2 CBQ
At T1 and T2, parents and teachers reported (1 = extremely 
untrue; 7 = extremely true) on children’s attentional focusing 
and inhibitory control subscales of the CBQ, which are the 
subdimensions of effortful control (Rothbart et al., 2001; e.g., 
“Can lower his/her voice when asked to do so” and “When 
watching TV, is easily distracted by other noises or move-
ments” (latter item was reverse‐coded). Eight separate par-
ent‐ and teacher‐reported T1 or T2 attentional focusing and 
inhibitory control subscales were computed by averaging the 
items for each of the subscales within each reporter at both 
T1 and T2. Cronbach’s alpha for parent‐reported attentional 
focusing was 0.91 (T1) and 0.72 (T2), for parent‐reported 
inhibitory control as 0.84 (T1) and 0.81 (T2), for teacher‐
reported attentional focusing was 0.85 (T1) and 0.82 (T2), 
and for teacher‐reported inhibitory control was 0.88 (T1) and 
0.90 (T2).
T1 and T2 puzzle box task
This task assesses children’s persistence in the face of a 
challenge and has been considered a measure of attention 
focusing and/or inhibitory control (Eisenberg et al., 1996; 
Eisenberg et al., 2004). It was administered at both T1 and 
T2. Children sat in front of a 24 in. × 12 in. × 14 in. box that

contained a puzzle. The back of the box was clear Plexiglas 
to facilitate observations of children’s hand movements, and 
the front of the box was covered by a cloth that had sleeves 
through which children could slip their arms. This cloth 
could be lifted so that children could look at the puzzle. The 
children were told to try and put the puzzle together without 
looking and if they finished in 5 min at T1 or 4 min at T2, 
they would receive an attractive prize. Task scores reflected 
the amount of time the child persisted on the task rather than 
cheating or being off task. These scores were computed by 
dividing the number of seconds the child worked on the puz-
zle without cheating by the number of seconds the child was 
alone with the task. Interrater reliabilities were r = 0.99 at T1 
and r = 0.96 at T2.
T1 and T2 sitting still task
The sitting still task assessed children’s ability to inhibit 
movements when asked to do so (because they had physi-
ological equipment attached to their body) and has been 
considered a measure of effortful behavioral regulation 
(Eisenberg et al., 2001). At both T1 and T2, children were 
told that they would be watching two short films and to sit 
still while viewing them so the equipment did not come off. 
The experimenter pretended to start the film (nothing came 
on) and left the room. During this time, children were left 
alone and videotaped for 1 min. Coders rated the movement 
of the left hand (where the skin conductance electrode was 
attached) on a 4‐point scale (1 = no movement, 4 = small 
movements such as wiggling fingers for >40 s, or two big 
movements, such as moving the arm). Coders also rated 
global body movements (heart rate electrodes were on the 
trunk of the body) on a 5‐point scale (1 = no movement, 
5 = small movements for three‐fourth of the time, such as 
tapping feet or slightly moving head, or four big movements, 
such as moving the head 90° or body shifting). At T1 and T2, 
correlations between hand and body movements were 0.55 
and 0.60, respectively (p < 0.001). Interrater reliabilities for 
hand and body movement ratings were 0.94 and 0.99 at T1, 
respectively, and were both 0.77 at T2. Children’s ability to 
sit still was computed at both T1 and T2 by standardizing and 
averaging scores for the hand and global body movements 
at each time point. Scores were reverse coded so that greater 
scores indicated children’s greater ability to sit still (i.e., cor-
responding with greater levels of effortful control).
T1 and T3 resiliency
At T1 and T3, parents reported (1 = most undescriptive, 
9 = most descriptive) on children’s ego resiliency (henceforth 
called resiliency)—viewed as a dispositional characteristic—
using items derived from Block and Block’s Q‐sort (Block & 
Block, 1980). The Blocks’ original items, which were rated 
by clinicians, were further refined because the range of con-
tent was broad. Items were selected if experts in the field 
(faculty and students studying self‐regulation and related top-
ics) rated them as tapping resiliency, but not adjustment, so-
cial competence, or emotionality (see Eisenberg et al., 1996, 
for details). These items were further refined to create a yet 
purer measure of resiliency using 10 experts’ ratings of how 
much each item reflected pure resiliency (Cumberland‐Li 
et al., 2004). Eleven items were retained (e.g., Eisenberg et 
al., 2003). Note that these procedures also served to reduce 
overlap of resiliency with questionnaire measures of effortful 
control and impulsivity, which is illustrated by their low‐to‐
moderate intercorrelations (see Table 2). Cronbach’s alpha 
was 0.71 for T1 and T3 reports of resiliency. Some items 
included, “Can bounce back and recover after a stressful or 
bad experience” and “Freezes up when things are stressful, or 
else keeps doing the same thing over and over again.”
2.3.4  |  Data analytic plan
Analyses were conducted in Mplus v.7.11 using maximum 
likelihood with robust standard errors and full information 
maximum likelihood (Muthén & Muthén, 1998–2013).
Bifactor modeling
We created a bifactor model using data from multiple report-
ers and measurement occasions. To account for reporter‐spe-
cific method variance, we modeled method factors, similar 
to several previous studies (e.g., Keiley, Lofthouse, Bates, 
Dodge, & Pettit, 2003; Wang et al., 2015). Data from two 
time points (T1 and T2) were used because we wanted to 
capture stable and trait‐like temperamental processes, avoid 
capturing state‐like processes that could occur using only one 
time point, and because it allowed us to include ratings of 
two teachers per child, as well as the parent. The decision to 
combine T1 and T2 indicators is supported by the high stabil-
ity of effortful control and impulsivity from T1 to T2. For ex-
ample, the same parent‐reported subscales assessed at T1 and 
T2 were highly and significantly correlated (rs = 0.60–0.81) 
and the same teacher‐reported subscales at T1 and T2 showed 
significant, moderate‐to‐high correlations despite being re-
ported by different teachers (rs = 0.40–0.58; see Table 2). 
Moreover, the number of indicators at T1 or T2 alone was 
insufficient to support model convergence; subscales (not 
items) were used as indicators and, for example, there were 
only two measures of impulsivity at each time point. The ef-
fortful control indicators were T1 and T2 parent‐ and teacher‐
reported attention focusing and inhibitory control subscales, 
T1 and T2 puzzle box task, and T1 and T2 sitting still task 
(eight indicators). The impulsivity indicators were T1 and T2 
parent‐ and teacher‐reported impulsivity (four indicators).
To estimate the bifactor model, we specified that all ef-
fortful control indicators load on a pure effortful control 
factor, all impulsivity indicators load on a pure impul-
sivity factor, and all indicators load on a general control

factor. To account for reporter‐specific method variance, 
all parent‐reported indicators loaded onto a parent report 
factor, all T1 teacher‐reported indicators loaded onto a T1 
teacher report factor, and all T2 teacher‐reported indicators 
loaded onto a T2 teacher report factor (T1 and T2 teachers 
were not the same). Note, we did not model method‐spe-
cific variance from the behavioral tasks. The puzzle box 
is relatively objective and would not be expected to have 
substantial method variance. The sitting still task was rated 
by a variety of different coders across each time point, sug-
gesting little shared method variance.
The pure effortful control, pure impulsivity, and general 
control factors were specified to be uncorrelated with one 
another to establish orthogonal factors that represent unique 
variance after partialling out variance due to other factors. 
The pure and general factors were also specified to be un-
correlated with parent and teacher report factors because, by 
definition, trait and method factors should be uncorrelated 
and independent (Geiser, Bishop, & Lockhart, 2015). Parent 
and teacher report factors were allowed to correlate because 
there is likely to be a relation between these method fac-
tors (e.g., all three are indicated by self‐report inventories). 
Indicators that did not load onto their respective factors at 
p < 0.05 were deleted from the model.
Final models
We ran one model predicting T3 resiliency that did not 
control for T1 resiliency, which allowed us to examine re-
lations between temperamental traits and resiliency over 
time. We ran a second model predicting T3 resiliency that 
did control for T1 resiliency to examine whether tempera-
mental traits predicted resiliency above and beyond what 
could be explained by T1 resiliency. In the first model, 
covariates (T1 age, sex, parent education) and predictors 
(pure effortful control, pure impulsivity, general control 
factors) were entered into a first block in predicting T3 
resiliency (main effect model). In a second block, the fol-
lowing latent variable interactions were created using the 
XWITH and type = random commands in Mplus and added 
to the model: pure effortful control‐by‐sex and ‐by‐age, 
pure impulsivity‐by‐sex and ‐by‐age, and general control‐
by‐sex and ‐by‐age. Nonsignificant interactions (p < 0.05) 
were trimmed. The same procedures were followed for the 
second model, except we included T1 resiliency as a co-
variate. Given α = 0.05, this study is adequately powered 
(0.82) to assess the increase in explained variance due to 
an interaction of small effect (f2 = 0.04). In all models we 
included T1 and/or T3 parent‐reported resiliency on the 
aforementioned parent‐report method factor to model this 
reporter‐specific measurement variance. Covariates were 
mean‐centered. Interaction terms were probed using simple 
slope analyses (Aiken & West, 1991), calculated using the 
Model Constraint command in Mplus.
3  | 
RESULTS
See Table 1 for descriptive statistics separately by sex.
3.1  |  Zero‐order correlations
Higher levels of T3 resiliency were significantly cor-
related with higher levels of T1 resiliency, higher levels 
of parent‐reported effortful control, and higher levels of 
T1 teacher‐reported inhibitory control (see Table 2). T3 
resiliency was not correlated with any other teacher‐re-
ported temperament measures, behavioral measures, par-
ent‐reported impulsivity, age, sex, or parental education. 
T1 resiliency was positively related to most T1 measures 
(parent‐reported temperament, teacher‐reported effortful 
control, behavioral measures), but not to most T2 tempera-
ment measures (although it was positively, significantly re-
lated to both reports of inhibitory control, parents’ reports 
of attention focusing and teachers’ reports of impulsivity). 
Girls generally showed greater levels of effortful control 
and lower levels of impulsivity than boys across reporters 
and modes of measurement, but there was no sex differ-
ence in resiliency.
3.2  |  Bifactor model
See Table 3 for factor loadings and retained indicators for 
the final bifactor model of effortful control and impulsiv-
ity. For the pure effortful control factor, the only indicators 
that were retained (p < 0.05) were T1 and T2 parent‐re-
ported attention focusing and T1 teacher‐reported atten-
tion focusing. All other effortful control indicators (i.e., 
T1 and T2 parent‐ and teacher‐reported inhibitory control, 
T2 teacher‐reported attention focusing, T1 and T2 puzzle 
box, and T1 and T2 sitting still) were deleted from the pure 
effortful control factor. For the pure impulsivity factor, all 
four T1 and T2 parent‐ and teacher‐reported impulsivity 
items were retained (p < 0.05). For the general control fac-
tor, all indicators (16) were retained (p < 0.05). Reporter‐
specific factors were significantly correlated with one 
another, rs = 0.43–0.51, p < 0.001. Model fit was good: 
χ2 (84) = 131, p < 0.001, RMSEA = 0.05, CFI = 0.97, 
SRMR = 0.047 (note that model fit and coefficients re-
mained nearly identical when compared to a model that 
retained all paths). Although some indicators loaded less 
than what might be considered “substantial” on their factor 
(e.g., standardized factor loading <0.30), these indicators 
typically loaded above 0.30 on the other factor and/or had 
an R2 that was quite high, above 0.45. Moreover, the pat-
tern and magnitude of loadings were similar to bifactor 
models from a previous study (Wang, Eisenberg, Valiente, 
& Spinrad, 2016).

3.3  |  Final models
For the model that did not control for T1 resiliency, the pure 
effortful control‐by‐sex and pure impulsivity‐by‐sex interac-
tions were significant. For the model that did control for T1 
resiliency, the pure impulsivity‐by‐sex interaction was sig-
nificant. The rest of the interaction terms were trimmed. See 
Table 4 for coefficients of final models and Figure 1 for path 
diagrams.
3.3.1  |  Without controlling for T1 resiliency
In the first main effects block, higher levels of pure impulsiv-
ity and pure effortful control predicted higher levels of T3 
resiliency. The general control factor, age, sex, and parental 
education did not significantly predict T3 resiliency.
In the second interaction block, the significant pure ef-
fortful control‐by‐sex interaction was such that higher lev-
els of pure effortful control predicted higher levels of T3 
resiliency for girls, b = 0.55, p = 0.001, but not for boys, 
b = 0.08, p = 0.51. The significant pure impulsivity‐by‐sex 
interaction was such that higher levels of pure impulsivity 
significantly predicted higher levels of T3 resiliency for 
girls, b = 0.47, p < 0.001, but not for boys, b = 0.06, 
p = 0.60.
3.3.2  |  Controlling for T1 resiliency
In the first main effects block, higher levels of T1 resiliency sig-
nificantly predicted higher levels of T3 resiliency. The effect 
of pure effortful control on T3 resiliency tended toward but did 
not reach statistical significance. Pure impulsivity, general con-
trol, age, sex, and parent education did not predict T3 resiliency. 
In the second interaction block, the significant pure impulsiv-
ity‐by‐sex interaction was such that higher levels of impulsivity 
significantly predicted higher levels of T3 resiliency for girls, 
b = 0.27, p = 0.01, but not for boys, b = −0.14, p = 0.22.
4  | 
DISCUSSION
We tested a bifactor model of effortful control and impul-
sivity in childhood to gain a better understanding of these 
temperamental constructs and their overlap. In addition, we

4.1  |  Interpretation of the common and 
specific factors
The bifactor model was such that all effortful control and im-
pulsivity indicators (including behavioral measures and adult 
reports) loaded on the general control factor (with impulsiv-
ity loading negatively), only attentional focusing indicators 
(except T2 teacher‐reported attentional focusing) loaded on 
the pure effortful control factor, and all impulsivity indica-
tors loaded on the pure impulsivity factor. This model struc-
ture was somewhat different from our original hypotheses 
because we expected all effortful control items to load onto 
the pure effortful control factor. Because of this difference, 
a couple of the factors are not reflective of what they were 
originally named (i.e., pure effortful control, pure impulsivity 
and general control).
Although not originally hypothesized, in retrospect, the 
bifactor model findings make some sense. We conjecture 
that the general control factor reflects primarily effortful in-
hibitory control. Indeed, it is inhibitory control (or the lack 
thereof), especially as applied to overt, observable behavior, 
that is probably most in common for effortful control and im-
pulsivity. Moreover, effortful attentional control likely con-
tributes to the effortful inhibition of behavior, for example, by 
focusing on alternative courses of behavior and modulating 
emotion that affects the overt expression of emotion. If the 
general control factor does reflect effortful inhibitory control, 
this suggests that adults’ observations of children’s high im-
pulsivity sometimes erroneously reflects low effortful inhib-
itory control and observations of children’s low impulsivity 
sometimes erroneously reflects high effortful inhibitory con-
trol. Thus, the overlap between effortful control and impul-
sivity might partially reflect that impulsivity items pick up on 
low effortful inhibitory control to a certain extent. We refer to 
the general control factor as the “common effortful inhibitory 
control” factor from this point forward. The pure impulsivity 
factor likely reflects the remaining variance associated with 
impulsivity items (e.g., spontaneity), and could represent a 
purer version of impulsivity that does not reflect a lack of 
effortful control (e.g., approach‐related behaviors that are not 
due to lack of inhibitory control).
The factor that contained the attentional focusing scales 
(all except T2 teacher‐reported attentional focusing) is 
slightly more difficult to interpret. We hereafter refer to this 
factor as the pure attentional control factor. One hypothesis 
is that this pure attentional control factor reflects effort-
ful attentional control involved in aspects of self‐regulation 
other than the effortful inhibition of overt behavior. Indeed, 
effortful attentional control also contributes to the inhibition 
of cognitions (labeled attentional inhibition by Nigg, 2017), 
and this might be what is captured by the separate pure atten-
tional control factor. Thus, children with high scores on the 
pure attentional control factor may be skilled at controlling 
cognitive interference and in regulating internal emotional 
states (Friedman & Miyake, 2004). The pure attentional con-
trol factor could also reflect aspects of executive functioning 
that contribute to self‐regulation, and particularly those as-
pects that pertain to the inhibition of cognition, perhaps al-
lowing for cognitive flexibility (e.g., shifting one’s thoughts 
to respond to situations in different ways; Anderson, 2002). 
This factor might also partly reflect the executive attention 
network, which is a neural substrate underlying the devel-
opment of effortful control and that is responsible for mon-
itoring and resolving conflict among other brain networks 
(Rothbart, Sheese, & Posner, 2007). Given that executive at-
tention likely underlies effortful control, and that aspects of 
executive functioning contribute to self‐regulation (Eisenberg 
& Zhou, 2016), it makes sense that items designed to mea-
sure effortful control (and particularly attentional regulation) 
might also tap executive attention and a variety of processes 
involved in self‐regulation through attentional control.
However, we are unsure why T2 teacher‐reported atten-
tional focusing did not load on the pure attentional control 
factor. Perhaps at older ages (compared to at a younger age), 
internal attentional processes used to regulate cognitions and 
emotions are more difficult for teachers to report accurately 
because children become more independent in performing 
classroom activities. Finally, it is noteworthy that the be-
havioral measures used in this study (i.e., puzzle box and 
sitting still tasks) loaded onto the common effortful inhibi-
tory control factor, but not the pure attentional control fac-
tor. This suggests that the puzzle box and sitting still tasks 
primarily reflect effortful inhibitory control and attentional 
control processes that serve to regulate overt behaviors at the 
ages assessed in this study (4.5–10 years old). Moreover, it 
seems that these tasks do not reflect the aspect of children’s 
attentional control that serves to regulate internal emotions 
and cognitions not necessarily related to controlling overt 
behavior.
4.2  |  Prediction of resiliency
We also found that the childhood temperamental factors 
were associated with resiliency measured in late childhood/
early adolescence. The pure impulsivity factor had a main 
effect on resiliency, such that higher levels of pure impul-
sivity predicted higher levels of resiliency. This main effect 
did not hold after controlling for earlier resiliency. However, 
pure impulsivity was moderated by sex in predicting resil-
iency both with and without controlling for prior resiliency. 
Specifically, higher levels of pure impulsivity were associ-
ated with higher levels of resiliency for girls, but pure impul-
sivity did not significantly predict resiliency for boys. Our 
results are consistent with previous studies showing that that 
it might be low impulsivity in particular that undermines the 
development of resiliency, with pure impulsivity reflecting a

See the Terms and Conditions (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/terms-and-conditions) on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License

capacity for spontaneity (e.g., Eisenberg et al., 2002, 2003). 
It is worth noting that impulsivity and T3 resiliency were not 
associated in zero‐order correlations (see Table 2). Thus, re-
moving overlap with effortful control makes impulsivity a 
more robust predictor of resiliency (Eisenberg et al., 2002, 
2003). Results highlight the need to rigorously distinguish 
among traits that are conceptually and empirically distinct 
but may overlap strongly with other constructs due to the 
measurement, such as impulsivity and effortful control. More 
careful attention to these issues might help elucidate the role 
of temperament in many outcomes of interest.
Although we did not hypothesize a sex‐specific effect, 
perhaps pure impulsivity predicted resiliency only for girls 
because girls are more likely than boys to be low in impul-
sivity (see Table 2; Else‐Quest et al., 2006). If the positive 
association between resiliency and impulsivity is only ap-
parent at more extreme low levels of impulsivity (as found 
by Eisenberg et al., 2002), which is more characteristic of 
girls, perhaps this explains the gender‐specific effect. Girls 
low in impulsivity may show lower resiliency because they 
react in more constrained ways to stressful circumstances that 
are novel.
The current investigation is one of few studies examin-
ing how pure effortful attentional control, which more purely 
reflects the attentional regulation of internal states, predicts 
resiliency. Without controlling prior resiliency, we found that 
the pure attentional control factor significantly predicted re-
siliency and was moderated by sex, such that higher levels 
of pure attentional control were associated with higher lev-
els of resiliency for girls only. However, these effects were 
no longer significant after controlling for T1 resiliency. This 
pattern of results calls into question the directionality of this 
association (in regard to causality).
Nonetheless, findings from the model that did not con-
trol for T1 resiliency provide preliminary evidence that the 
use of pure attentional control as an internal regulatory pro-
cess is important in the development of resiliency, and that 
these skills might be more important for girls than for boys. 
Perhaps pure attentional control shows some links with re-
siliency because it contributes to cognitive flexibility, which 
is the ability to switch between thoughts or think about mul-
tiple concepts simultaneously (Anderson, 2002). Deficits 
in this skill could lead to greater challenges in responding 
to new situations in different ways (perhaps especially for 
girls), resulting in diminished resiliency. Because attentional 
focusing is involved in regulating the internal experience 
of emotion (Wadlinger & Isaacowitz, 2011), children with 
lower scores on the pure attentional control factor (and per-
haps especially girls) might show lower resiliency because 
they are less able than children with higher attentional con-
trol to manage emotions when stressed. These findings re-
quire replication because they were not consistent across all 
models.
This is also one of few studies to examine how the ef-
fortful inhibitory control of overt behaviors, independent of 
effortful attentional control over purely internal states, pre-
dicts resiliency. We did not find that the common effortful 
inhibitory control factor uniquely predicted resiliency in any 
models. However, zero‐order correlations showed consistent 
associations between effortful control subscales and resil-
iency. Post‐hoc analyses helped reconcile this discrepancy; 
analyses showed that the common effortful inhibitory control 
factor significantly predicted resiliency prior to adding the 
T1 and/or T3 resiliency scales onto the parent‐report method 
factor. The significant zero‐order correlations between T1 
and/or T3 resiliency and indicators of effortful control likely 
reflect shared reporter effects that do not persist once method 
variance is taken into account in the final model. Findings 
suggest that the ability to effortfully inhibit overt behaviors 
(that is independent of impulsivity and effortful attentional 
control) is not related to the development of resiliency.
4.3  |  Differences by sex and age
The sex moderation pattern found in the current study might 
shed some light on the development of resiliency for boys 
versus girls. It is noteworthy that pure attentional control (al-
beit only without controlling T1 resiliency) and pure impul-
sivity were only predictive of resiliency for girls, but not for 
boys. This finding suggests that other factors, such as learn-
ing styles, experiences, and other temperamental traits might 
predict resiliency for boys at this age. Additionally, perhaps 
pure impulsivity, effortful attentional control, and/or effort-
ful inhibitory control would predict boys’ resiliency during 
a different developmental window. In contrast, the develop-
ment of girls’ resiliency at this age appears to be more reliant 
upon their spontaneity and, to a lesser extent, their control 
over internal states, but not upon their effortful inhibition of 
overt behaviors. It is not difficult to imagine that some girls 
facing stress may have the capacity to voluntarily regulate 
behaviors according to external demands (i.e., sitting still, 
following rules); however, they may remain internally dis-
tressed because they cannot spontaneously pursue other ave-
nues to cope or effortfully re‐direct attention from distressing 
emotions or cognitions.
Previous studies have not found similar sex differences in 
the prediction of resiliency by effortful control and impulsiv-
ity (Cumberland‐Li et al., 2004; Eisenberg et al., 2002, 2004). 
This difference might be due to our use of a multi‐method 
and ‐reporter bifactor model that more accurately teases apart 
overlap among these temperamental traits and accounts for 
reporter bias. Our sex‐dependent findings are in line with 
previous research suggesting that resiliency follows different 
developmental trajectories for girls and boys (Chuang et al., 
2006); our findings similarly suggest that resiliency could 
have a distinct etiology for girls compared to boys.

Finally, we tested whether any of the factors in the bifactor 
model were moderated by age in predicting resiliency. Our 
findings suggest that these constructs do not differently pre-
dict resiliency by age. However, it is possible that age mod-
eration was not found because of the relatively limited age 
range. Each wave had a 4‐year age span among participants. 
Perhaps age differences in the prediction of resiliency appear 
after greater time lags. Indeed, prior research showed that the 
effect of impulsivity may grow stronger with age (Valiente et 
al., 2003). Future research should examine age moderation in 
a sample with greater age heterogeneity.
4.4  |  Strengths, limitations, and conclusions
The current study had several limitations. We did not test 
three‐way interactions among temperament, sex, and age due 
to a probable lack of power and because, although the extant 
literature shows that gender differences may differ by age, 
these effects may only emerge later in adolescence than cap-
tured in this study (e.g., Wade, Cairney, & Pevalin, 2002). 
The lack of sufficient age heterogeneity within each wave 
might have limited our ability to detect age moderation. We 
could not test a quadratic effect of impulsivity on resiliency 
(as found in Eisenberg et al., 2002) because this model un-
fortunately did not converge. Similarly, because participants 
who dropped out of the study had lower teacher‐reported at-
tention focusing, a restricted range in this variable could have 
explained the nonsignificant loading of the teacher‐reported 
attention focusing indicator on the pure attentional control 
factor. Because the current sample consisted of mostly non‐
Hispanic Caucasian children, results may not be generaliz-
able to other racial/ethnic groups. Research investigating 
differences in these relations by race/ethnicity is warranted. 
Future research investigating additional outcomes that show 
differential prediction by the factors discovered in this study 
will also help clarify the meaning of the latent factors.
The current study had several strengths. We used behav-
ioral measures coded by observers as well as parents’ and 
teachers’ reports of effortful control and impulsivity in our 
bifactor model. We partialled out method variance due to par-
ent and teacher reporter bias and controlled for baseline mea-
sures of resiliency to yield prospective analyses. Our use of 
a bifactor model also increased understanding of the overlap 
between effortful control and impulsivity.
This investigation yielded several insights into the pro-
spective effects of effortful control and impulsivity on 
resiliency. Effortful control and impulsivity might show 
overlap partly because reports of impulsivity tap low ef-
fortful inhibitory control. Questionnaire reports of atten-
tional focusing might capture internal regulatory processes 
that help children control their overt behavior (i.e., effort-
ful inhibitory control), as well as their cognitions and emo-
tions, and these two processes might be somewhat distinct. 
After disentangling effortful inhibitory control, impulsiv-
ity, and attentional control, their prediction of resiliency 
was somewhat different than in the previous literature and 
dependent upon sex. The pure impulsivity factor, and, to a 
lesser extent, the pure attentional control factor, predicted 
girls’ resiliency, suggesting that resiliency is more deter-
mined by girls’ control‐related temperamental traits. None 
of the factors predicted resiliency for boys, suggesting that 
other variables may be more prominent in the development 
of boys’ resiliency at this age. Results suggest that teaching 
girls to be more flexible and spontaneous in the face of 
stress, as well as strategies to employ attentional control, 
may foster greater resiliency; more research is needed to 
understand how to improve boys’ resiliency. Disentangling 
the common and unique aspects of temperamental traits 
may be an important step toward illuminating the role of 
temperament in the development of future outcomes.

Über das, was unter einem Ritual zu verstehen ist, herrscht in der modernen
Gesellschaft wenig Klarheit. Dies gilt sowohl für den umgangssprachlichen
Gebrauch des Wortes im Alltag wie in den Diskussionen auf wissenschaftlicher
Ebene, sei es in der Ethnologie, der Religionswissenschaft oder auch innerhalb der
Gesellschaftswissenschaften. Nahezu jedes beliebige Verhalten und Handeln kann
gegenwärtig offenbar als Ritual bezeichnet werden: Von der Taufe bis zur
Beerdigung, von den privaten Tischsitten bis hin zur öffentlichen Einweihung einer
neuen Autobahnbrücke, von der individuellen rituellen Waschung bis zur
kollektiven rituellen Rebellion – alles gilt als Ritual. So existieren angeblich
zyklische, magische, religiöse, säkulare, bürgerliche, militärische, politische,
sexuelle und ästhetische Rituale. Ganz ähnlich steht es mit der Einschätzung der
vermeintlichen Leistungsfähigkeit des Rituals – dem Ritual wird quasi eine
Omnipotenz zugesprochen. Angeblich ist es in der Lage, Neulinge zu integrieren,
Abweichler auszusondern, Trauernden Halt zu geben, Missetäter zu ächten; mit
Hilfe ritueller Techniken kann man Respekt bezeugen, Konflikte regeln, Solidarität
herstellen, Ängste bannen, Dank bekunden, Identität sichern, ... die Aufzählung
ließe 
sich 
fortsetzen. 
Kurz 
gesagt 
läßt 
sich 
bezüglich 
der 
rituellen
Leistungsfähigkeit feststellen: Gemäß dem gewöhnlichen Alltagsverständnis kann
nicht nur jedweder in gewisser Stereotypie auftretender Handlungsablauf für ein
Ritual gehalten werden, sondern es wird auch – salopp formuliert – unterstellt: Das
Ritual kann (fast) alles!
Dem Ritual als einem Problemlösungsverfahren wird ein hohes Maß an Vertrauen
entgegengebracht wird. Damit ist gemeint, daß einzelne soziale Akteure, eine
Vielzahl unterschiedlich klar strukturierter sozialer Gemeinschaften, aber auch
etablierte gesellschaftliche Institutionen sich auch in der modernen Gesellschaft
offensichtlich gern ritueller Praktiken bedienen, und dies nicht nur, wenn es darum
geht, unvertraute, emotionsgeladene, heikle oder gar unangenehme Situationen zu
bewältigen. Beachtet man beispielsweise Phänomene wie die Zunahme von
Osterfeierlichkeiten in den Kirchengemeinden einer Großstadt wie Frankfurt am

 Interessant ist nun, daß gerade auch im Zuge der kritischen Auseinandersetzung
mit rituellen Handlungen etwas über die Bedeutung des Rituals selbst klar wird:
Eine genauere Interpretation der praktischen Widerstandsformen gegen das Ritual,
wie sie hier exemplarisch anhand der Analyse des Großen Zapfenstreichs

modernen Gesellschaft nebeneinander bestehenden gegensätzlichen Haltungen zum

Soeffner behauptet, daß die beiden skizzierten Positionen sich als Ausdruck einer
Einstellung, nämlich der eines „undurchschauten Ritualismus„ auffassen lassen,

Vor der hier zu entwickelnden Analyse der konkreten Zapfenstreichzeremonie sind
einige grungsätzliche Bemerkungen zum erwendeten Ritualverständnis er-
forderlich.
Zunächst ist festzuhalten, daß rituelles Verhalten - wie nahezu jedes menschliche
Handeln -  als ein sinngebendes, Sinn und Bedeutung zuschreibendes und
vermittelndes Verhalten zu verstehen ist.5 In Abhebung von streng zweckrationalen
Handlungen kommt dem rituellen Handeln allerdings vorrangig eine „symbolische
Rationalität„ zu6, es ist gewissermaßen als die „Aktionsform des Symbols„7 zu
begreifen.  Als solches ist es in der Regel ein soziales Handeln, das heißt, es ist
sinnhaft auf das Verhalten oder den Status anderer bezogen. Unter einem Ritual
wird deshalb hier - in enger Anlehnung an Erving Goffman -  eine Handlung oder
Handlungssequenz  verstanden,  durch die die beteiligten Akteure ihre
Wertschätzung gegenüber anderen Akteuren oder gegenüber einem Wert
(Symbol), der den Status einer Gemeinschaft oder Gesellschaft repräsentiert,
bekunden.8 Die Funktion des Rituals besteht also darin, eine Aussage über die
Bedeutung oder die Gültigkeit einer eigenen oder fremden Norm- oder
Werthaltung zu machen. In dieser grundsätzlichen Wirkungsweise werden Rituale
für die Konstitution des Alltags einer jeden Gesellschaft immens wichtig.9 Die
jeweils der speziellen rituellen Inszenierung zugrunde liegenden Motive und
Absichten können, wie eingangs schon anhand einiger Beispiele erwähnt, vielfältig
orientiert sein. Die konkrete Ausgestaltung des Rituals kann ebenfalls verschiedene

7 Soeffner (1995), S.4, Hervorhebung von Soeffner.
8 Vgl. Goffman (1974), S. 97; Goffman (1978).
9 Der Begriff des Alltags wird hier im Sinne des von Alfred Schütz entfalteten
Verständnis der „Lebenswelt des Alltags„ als einer „ausgezeichneten Wirklichkeitt„
(paramount reality) gebraucht. (Vgl. Schütz/Luckmann (1979, 1994)).Von seiner
Konzeption des Alltags ausgehend, läßt sich in der Tat „...fundamentaler die Leistung
des Rituals beschreiben, fundamentaler in dem Sinne, daß es darum geht, wie sich die
Teilnehmenden selbst auf den Alltag (...) beziehen. Hauschildt (1993), S. 228.

Formen annehmen; sie ist letztlich vom Selbstverständnis, den Traditionen, den
jeweiligen kulturellen Kontexten der praktizierenden Gemeinschaften abhängig. So
werden beispielsweise in fast allen Gesellschaften und Gemeinschaften
Aufnahmerituale vollzogen, die gewisse strukturelle Gemeinsamkeiten aufweisen,
sich beispielsweise auf die Kernelemente einer Taufhandlung zurückführen lassen.
Daß aber alle Ritualformen letztlich gerade durch ihre spezifische Gestaltungsweise
die jeweilige Gemeinschaft konstituieren und in ihrer Identität stabilisieren, macht
das Ritual auch in der modernen Gesellschaft zu einem besonders leistungsfähigen
sozialen Verfahren. Auch dies wird sich in der Analyse des Großen Zapfenstreich-
Rituals beispielhaft zeigen lassen. Sie soll in einem darstellenden Teil und einer
darauf folgenden soziologischen Analyse in fünf Schritten vorgenommen werden:
Der darstellende Teil bemüht sich, die konkrete Inszenierung des Großen
Zapfenstreichs, wie er am 26. Oktober 1995 aus Anlaß des vierzigjährigen
Bestehens der Bundeswehr begangen wurde, so detailliert wie möglich zu
beschreiben. (1)  Im ersten Analyseschritt wird zunächst die Entstehung und das
„klassische„ Schema des Handlungsablaufs der Zapfenstreichzeremonie dargelegt.
Anhand des formalen Ablaufschemas wird sich bereits das elementare Muster eines
Passagerituals herauskristallisieren lassen.(2.1) Der zweite Analyseschritt geht auf
die Tradition soldatischer Rituale in Deutschland ein. Hier wird deutlich werden,
daß sie seit jeher ein Anlaß scharfer kritischer Auseinandersetzung waren.(2.2) Mit
der unmittelbaren Vorgeschichte der Zapfensreichzeremonie vom 25. 10. 1995
beschäftigt sich der dritte Teil. (2.3)  Im vierten und fünften Schritt folgt dann die
Interpretation des kompletten Handlungszusammenhangs. Besondere Berücksichti-
gung erfahren dabei die antiritualistischen Motive der Zapfenstreichgegner (2.4)
sowie die Repräsentationsleistungen zugunsten des soldatischen Alltags. (2.5)

1 Die Inszenierung eines Rituals - Der Große Zapfenstreich im Bonner
Hofgarten
Im Fackelschein von fünfzig Fackeln in den Händen der Soldaten des Siegburger
Wachbatallions beginnt unter den Klängen des preußischen Präsentiermarsches
exakt um 20.30 Uhr der Einzug des Großen Zapfenstreichs in den Bonner
Hofgarten.10 Die Hofgartenwiese ist für dieses Ereignis bis ins kleinste vorbereitet
worden: Das Areal der Aufführung ist genau abgegrenzt und polizeilich gesichert
(Sicherheitsstufe I), die Zugangs- und Aufenthaltsbereiche für Ehrengäste,
Zuschauer und die Aufführenden sind klar getrennt und werden streng kontrolliert.
In zwei eigens dafür aufgestellten Zelten müssen die „herzlich eingeladenen„ Gäste
aus der Bonner Bevölkerung eine Ausweiskontrolle samt Leibesvisitation über sich
ergehen lassen.
Die Positionen, an denen die Mitwirkenden des Großen Zapfenstreichs Aufstellung
beziehen, sind vorher zentimetergenau vermessen und markiert worden. Zwei
Tribünen für Ehrengäste und Kamerateams sind an den Vortagen von einer
technischen Einheit (Soldaten des 320. Pionierbatallions Koblenz) der Bundeswehr
an den Längsseiten der Hofgartenwiese aufgebaut worden. Das Podium, auf dem
nebeneinander Verteidigungsminister Volker Rühe, Bundespräsident Roman
Herzog, Bundeskanzler Helmut Kohl und der Generalinspekteur der Bundeswehr,
Klaus Dieter Naumann, stehen, ist annähernd im Zentrum des Platzes aufgestellt.
Die vier Männer auf dem Podium sind alle in dunkler Hose und mit dunklen,
gleichlangen Mänteln gekleidet. Bis auf Generalinspekteur Naumann tragen sie
keine Kopfbedeckung. Die politischen Repräsentanten stehen, die Hände hinter
dem Rücken zusammengehalten mit leicht gespreizten Beinen, den Blick fest in die
gleiche 
Richtung 
genommen 
mit 
ernstem 
Gesichtsausdruck 
schweigend
nebeneinander. Der Repräsentant des Militärs, mit Offiziersmütze und Rangzeichen
auf den Schulterklappen, ist einen Schritt hinter ihnen postiert und hält die Hände
an der Hosennaht.

Für die ca. sechstausend anwesenden Zuschauer – eingeladen waren alle Bonner

Handlungsgeschehen ein Areal abgegrenzt. Der im Gleichschritt aufmarschierende
Große Zapfenstreich bezieht entlang der gesamten rückseitigen Fassade des
Universitätshauptgebäudes Aufstellung. Alle installierten Scheinwerfer und die
Parklaternen, die sonst zu dieser Zeit die Wege des Hofgarten beleuchten, sind
abgeschaltet, „um die Stimmung nicht zu stören„, wie der Kommentator der
Fernsehübertragung weiß.
Nachdem sich das Musikkorps mit Spielleuten samt seinem Begleitkommando
„unter Gewehr„ an den vorgezeichneten Stellen postiert hat, treten auf ein
Kommando je zwei Fackelträger rechts und links neben den Chef des Musikkorps,
zwei weitere an die Seiten des Podiums. Die rechts stehenden Soldaten halten ihre
Fackel dabei in der rechten Hand, die links stehenden in der linken, so daß sich ein
symmetrisches Bild ergibt. Je fünf Trommler, deren Trommeln mit orangefarbenen
Fahnen mit dem Emblem des Bundesadlers geschmückt sind, sind links und rechts
vom Dirigenten postiert und unterstreichen damit die symmetrische Ausrichtung.
Ein Tambourmajor rückt vor die Linie der Spielleute, ein Schellenbaumträger tritt
an den rechten Flügel des Musikkorps. Der den Großen Zapfenstreich anführende
Stabsoffizier begibt sich nun vor das Podest mit den vier Herren und meldet: „ Herr
Bundespräsident, Herr Bundeskanzler, ich melde: Großer Zapfenstreich zu Ehren
vierzig Jahre Bundeswehr, fünf Jahre Armee der Einheit angetreten!„ Der
Stabsoffizier erhält von Bundeskanzler Kohl offensichtlich eine Antwort, die aber
in der Übertragung nicht zu verstehen ist. Er wendet sich danach wieder der
angetretenen Formation zu und befiehlt: „Großer Zapfenstreich: Rührt Euch!
Augen geradeaus! Das Gewehr über! Das Gewehr ab! Serenade!„ Der Befehl wird
umgehend von den Angesprochenen mit nahezu absolut gleichförmigen
Handbewegungen ausgeführt. Von Anbeginn der Zeremonie an sind aus dem
Hintergrund Pfiffe und „Mörder, Mörder„-Rufe zu hören.
In der nun folgenden Serenade werden die einzelnen Bundeswehrstreitkräfte mit je
einem musikalischen Beitrag geehrt. Aus der klassischen militärischen
Musikliteratur wird für die Luftwaffe der Fliegermarsch intoniert, für die Marine
wird ein moderner Pop-Song, „I am sailing„, gespielt. Während der Serenade sind
als beständiges Hintergrundgeräusch Schreie, Johlen, Trillerpfeifen, „Mörder,

Mörder„-Rufe und „Humba, Humba, Täterä„-Gesänge zu hören. Nach Beendigung
der Serenade applaudieren Ehrengäste und Zuschauer. Dann erfolgt nach einer
kleinen Pause das nächste Kommando des leitenden Offiziers: „Großer
Zapfenstreich: Stillgestanden!„ Erneut eine kleine Pause. „Großer Zapfenstreich!„
Jetzt wird, von Trommlern und Pfeifern eingeleitet, der Große Zapfenstreich-

halten ihn in gleicher Höhe vor ihre Brust. Es folgt das Lied „Ich bete an die Macht

aus dem Hintergrund und das Jaulen von Handsirenen sind auch diesmal zu hören.
Der letzte Teil der Zeremonie beginnt mit dem Kommando: „Helm auf! Präsentiert
das Gewehr!„ Die Nationalhymne wird gespielt. Der kommandierende Offizier und
Generalinspekteur Naumann auf dem Podium haben ihre rechte Hand, den Arm
abgewinkelt, an ihre rechte Schläfe gelegt. Letzterer sowie der Bundespräsident,
der 
Bundeskanzler 
und 
der

singen 
– 
in

Fernsehübertragung allerdings nicht hörbar –  die Hymne. Auch für diese
musikalische Darbietung gibt es Applaus, aber auch Pfiffe. Zum Schluß erteilt der
Zapfenstreichkommandant der angetretenen Formation den Befehl „Zur Meldung:
Augen rechts!„ Er schreitet erneut vor das Podium, nimmt Haltung an und meldet:
„Herr Bundespräsident, Herr Bundeskanzler: Ich melde den Großen Zapfenstreich
zu Ehren vierzig Jahre Bundeswehr, fünf Jahre Armee der Einheit ab.„ An die
Zapfenstreichformation ergehen die Befehle: „Das Gewehr über! Das Gewehr ab!
Rechts um! Marsch!„ Begleitet von Lärmen und flackerndem Blaulicht aus dem
Hintergrund zieht der Große Zapfenstreich im Gleichmarsch ab.
Die oben beschriebene konkrete Inszenierung stützt sich auf eine Vorgabe mit
genauen Ausführungsanweisungen, gewissermaßen auf ein Drehbuch für die
Zeremonie. Dieses wiederum nimmt Bezug auf verschiedene historische Vorläufer
soldatischer Zapfenstreichhandlungen. Auf den geschichtlichen Hintergrund, der
zur Ausgestaltung der beschriebenen Zeremonie geführt hat, wird im folgenden
ersten Analyseschritt eingegangen.

Die soziologische Interpretation
2.1 Zur Entstehung und Form des Zapfenstreichrituals
Über die Herkunft, die Entwicklung und die Ausführungsmodalitäten des Großen
Zapfenstreiches gibt eine 32-seitige Broschüre mit dem Titel „Der Große
Zapfenstreich„ Auskunft, die Interessierten von der Medienredaktion des
Bundesministeriums der Verteidigung kostenlos zur Verfügung gestellt wird. Die
darin in deutscher, englischer und französischer Sprache abgedruckte „Skizze„
basiert auf einer „Studie„ des Ersten Musikinspizienten der Bundeswehr, Oberst a.
D. Wilhelm Stephan.11 Erwähnenswert ist diese Skizze einmal, weil sie als
offizielle, autorisierte Darstellung des Großen Zapfenstreiches seitens der
Bundesregierung gelten kann, und zum anderen, weil sie offensichtlich als Vorlage
für eine Reihe von Artikeln zur Sachinformation in der deutschen Tagespresse
diente.12 Soweit es in den weiteren Ausführungen um die heute noch befolgte
Praktizierung der hier dargelegten Durchführungsvorgabe geht, soll auf diese
Publikation Bezug genommen werden.
Zu Herkunft und historischer Entwicklung des Zapfenstreiches ist zu erwähnen,
daß die Bezeichnung „Zapfenstreich„ von einer bestimmten Handlung eines Profos
(also eines vorgesetzten Militärpolizisten) herrührt: Um am Abend das Ende eines
Trinkgelages beziehungsweise des Aufenthaltes in einem Wirtshaus zu verkünden,
schlug der Profos mit einem Stock auf den Zapfen eines Fasses. Quellen aus dem
17. Jahrhundert zufolge bedeutete diese Amtshandlung das Verbot des weiteren
Getränkeausschankes an die Soldaten an diesem Abend. Für die anwesenden
Soldaten bedeutete es weiterhin die sofortige Einstellung jedweden weiteren
Amüsements, also zum Beispiel zu zechen oder zu würfeln. Alle Feuer waren
sofort auszulöschen. Bei seinem Kontrollgang durch die Schänken und

ähnliche Darstellung zur Entwicklung des Zapfenstreichs gibt Stein (1984), S. 267-273.

(SZ) vom 27. 10. 1995, S. 2, unter der Rubrik „Aktuelles Lexikon„, im Rhein-Sieg-
Anzeiger unter der Rubrik „Stichwort„. In allen genannten Artikeln finden sich z. T.
wörtlich übernommene Passagen aus der erwähnten Schrift des
Verteidigungsministeriums.

Marketenderzelte wurde der Profos häufig von Musikanten, Trommlern und
Pfeifern begleitet. Nachdem der Zapfen gestrichen oder geschlagen worden war –
auch die Bezeichnung „Zapfenschlag„ ist gebräuchlich -hatte der Rückmarsch der
Truppe ins Heerlager unter Begleitung der Musiker „in gehöriger Ordnung„ zu
erfolgen; Zuwiderhandeln sollte „exemplariter abgestraffet werden„.
Diese symbolische Verkündung der Sperrstunde wurde 1726 von dem sächsischen
Major Hans von Fleming in seinem Buch „Der vollkommene deutsche Soldat„ als
Brauch des „Zapfenstreichs„ bezeichnet. Von König Friedrich Wilhelm III., der
wünschte, daß seine Truppen „auch in Hinsicht der Gottesverehrung keinen
anderen nachstehen„ sollten, erging am 10. August 1813 der Befehl
„Dass die Wachen von jetzt an, wenn Reveille oder Zapfenstreich
geschlagen wird, ins Gewehr treten, sodann das Gewehr präsentieren,
wieder schultern und abnehmen, hierauf den Czako usw. mit der linken
Hand abnehmen und, ihn mit beiden Händen vor dem Gesicht haltend,
ein stilles Gebet, etwa ein Vaterunser lang verrichten sollen.(...) In den
Feldlägern sollen die vor den Fahnen usw. versammelten Trompeter
oder Hoboisten gleich nach beendigtem Zapfenstreich ein kurzes
Abendlied blasen...„13
Die Einbeziehung eines Gebetes sowie eines Abendliedes bedeutet genau gesehen
eine Ausweitung der ursprünglichen Zapfenstreichhandlung. Besonders die
musikalische Erweiterung hat zu der heutigen Ausführungsform des Großen
Zapfenstreichs geführt, die die ursprüngliche Bedeutung nicht mehr durchscheinen
läßt. Die gegenwärtig praktizierte Form geht zurück auf eine Zusammenstellung
von musikalischen Elementen und dem Gebet durch den Direktor der Musikkorps
des Preußischen Gardekorps, Wilhelm Wieprecht, aus dem Jahr 1833. Danach
besteht ein Großer Zapfenstreich aus dem Zusammenwirken von Spielmannszug,
Musikkorps, Begleitkommando und Fackelträgern. Er wird von einem
Truppenoffizier geführt und kommandiert, der mindestens den Rang eines
Stabsoffiziers innehaben muß. Stephan beschreibt die heute gebräuchliche
Ausführung des Großen Zapfenstreichs wie folgt:
DUISBURGER BEITRÄGE zur SOZIOLOGISCHEN FORSCHUNG
13
13
„Der Große Zapfenstreich marschiert unter den Klängen eines
Armeemarsches auf den befohlenen Platz. Nach dem Halten wird eine
Linkswendung durchgeführt, der ein kurzes Ausrichten folgt. Auf ein
weiteres Kommando treten die Fackelträger, der Chef des Musikkorps,
der Tambourmajor, der Schellenbaumträger und evtl. der Kesselpauker
an ihre Plätze. Sodann erfolgt die Meldung des Großen Zapfenstreichs
an die zu ehrende Persönlichkeit.
Nach weiteren Kommandos beginnt nun üblicherweise eine Serenade in
Form von einigen Musikstücken nach Wahl des zu Ehrenden. Nach
Beendigung der Serenade beginnt auf das Kommando des
Truppenoffiziers sodann der Große Zapfenstreich in der oben
verzeichneten Spielfolge.
Vor dem Gebet erhalten die Waffenzüge das Kommando zum
Abnehmen, nach dem Gebet das Kommando zum Aufsetzen des
Helms. Der Große Zapfenstreich wird nach dem Spielen der
Nationalhymne durch den Truppenoffizier abgemeldet. Nachdem die
Fackelträger, der Chef des Musikkorps usw. ihre Marschplätze wieder
eingenommen haben, wird eine Rechtswendung ausgeführt. Mit einem
Wirbel von 8 Schritten und 8 Schlägen des Tambours und dem darauf
folgenden Zapfenstreich (Zapfenstreichmarsch) marschiert der Große
Zapfenstreich ab.„14
Im wesentlichen in dieser Form hat auch die Inszenierung des Großen
Zapfenstreichs durch ausgewählte Truppenteile der Bundeswehr am 26. 10. 1995
im Bonner Hofgarten stattgefunden.
Anlaß für das Abhalten eines Großen Zapfenstreichs ist gewöhnlich der Abschluß
eines größeren Manövers oder die Verabschiedung von höchsten militärischen
Führungspersonen. Seine Aufführung erfolgt dabei in der Bundeswehr seit 1957

14
14
„inhaltlich und formal überlieferungsgetreu„.15 In den letzten Jahren wird ein
Großer Zapfenstreich häufiger zu anderen Gelegenheiten, zum Beispiel bei
feierlichen Gelöbnissen von Wehrpflichtigen, eingesetzt.
Bezug nehmend auf diese Darstellung sollen zunächst lediglich zwei Aspekte
festgehalten werden:
(1) Anhand der knappen Schilderung der historischen Entwicklung vom
„Zapfenstreich„ zum „Großen Zapfenstreich„ dürfte schon deutlich werden, daß
das ursprüngliche Ritual der Trennung oder der Verabschiedung von einem
Zustand, der ein mehr oder weniger freies, zügelloses, jedenfalls weitgehend
ungeordnetes Verhalten erlaubte, in seiner heutigen Ausführungsweise nicht mehr
erkennbar ist. Der Moment der Markierung und Abgrenzung zwischen einem
Zustand relativ großer Desorganisation und eines solchen mit einem relativ hohen
Grad restriktiver Organisation ist abgelöst worden von einer zunehmend
ausdifferenzierten Präsentation des letzteren. Legt man Arnold van Genneps16
Schema des Übergangsritus zugrunde, so wird ersichtlich, daß die „präliminale„
und die „liminale„ Phase, in der der Übergang durch die „rites de séparation„
vorbereitet und durch die „rites de marge„ vollzogen wird, und die in etwa dem
Zapfenschlag oder Zapfenstreich des Profos und der Rückführung der Truppe ins
Lager entsprechen, in der aktuellen Ausführung des Großen Zapfenstreichs
verschwunden sind. Allein die „postlimilale„ Phase, in der der neue, hier der
wiederhergestellte, Status, zelebriert wird, ist erhalten geblieben, bzw. hat weitere
Ausschmückungen erfahren. In dieser Phase der Wiedereingliederung befindet sich
das „rituelle Subjekt„, wie Rainer Wiedenmann es in Bezug auf van Gennep und
Turner erläutert
„...wieder in einem relativ stabilen Zustand und hat demzufolge
anderen gegenüber klar definierte, sozialstrukturbedingte Rechte und
Pflichten„.17
